title: Bad flat_map optimization

labels.name: I-slow
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to performance of generated code.

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

body:
This is little test code for cartesian product of arrays:

```
#[inline(never)]
fn first_foo(a: &[u32], b: &[u32]) -> u32 {
    a.iter().map(|x| b.iter().map(|y| x * y).sum::<u32>()).sum()
}

#[inline(never)]
fn second_foo(a: &[u32], b: &[u32]) -> u32 {
    a.iter().flat_map(|x| b.iter().map(move |y| x * y)).sum()
}

fn main() {
    println!("{}", first_foo(&[1, 2, 3], &[10, 20, 30, 40]));
    println!("{}", first_foo(&[10, 20], &[100, 200, 300]));
    println!("{}", second_foo(&[1, 2, 3], &[10, 20, 30, 40]));
    println!("{}", second_foo(&[10, 20], &[100, 200, 300]));
}
```


Compiling with -O the rustc compiler is able to optimize first_foo() well, but it's unable to optimize well second_foo() with flat_map():


